content: The 9/11 Commission found that al Qaeda terrorists exploited weaknesses in aviation security, including lax screening, lack of in-flight security measures, and a failure of imagination among policymakers. The 9/11 Commission identified a failure of imagination among senior policymakers and agencies responsible for intelligence, national defense, and aviation security. There was a lack of specific actions taken to defend against possible threats like suicide hijackings before September 11, 2001. Congressional oversight of aviation security was also found to be lacking, with a focus on passenger service rather than terrorism. After the 9/11 attacks, Congress swiftly passed the Aviation and Transportation Security Act (ATSA) to address aviation security vulnerabilities. ATSA established the Transportation Security Administration (TSA) to oversee security in all transportation modes, including measures like federal security screeners at airports, explosive detection screening for checked bags, air marshals on high-risk flights, and reinforced cockpit doors. The Aviation and Transportation Security Act (ATSA) established the TSA to oversee security in all transportation modes, focusing on aviation security. The Homeland Security Act of 2002 placed the TSA within the Department of Homeland Security and authorized arming airline pilots. The Vision 100 Act included additional aviation security measures such as an aviation security capital fund for explosive detection systems and arming pilots of all-cargo aircraft. The Aviation and Transportation Security Act established the TSA to oversee aviation security, including arming pilots and implementing explosive detection systems. Despite improvements, vulnerabilities in air cargo operations, general aviation, access controls, screener performance, and potential terrorist attacks using shoulder-fired missiles persist. The 9/11 Commission identified these vulnerabilities and made recommendations for enhancing airport security. The 9/11 Commission made recommendations for airport security improvements, focusing on passenger and baggage screening, and air cargo security. They did not address risks related to inadequate access controls or shoulder-fired missile attacks. The Commission emphasized the need for a multi-layered security system that coordinates different security measures to effectively counter various terrorist tactics. The 9/11 Commission recommended enhancing passenger pre-screening, improving explosives detection on passengers, addressing human factors at screening checkpoints, deploying baggage screening systems, intensifying efforts to screen dangerous cargo, and using hardened cargo containers on passenger aircraft to improve aviation security. These recommendations aim to address vulnerabilities in commercial aviation and create redundancies in security measures. The Commission also advised setting transportation security priorities based on risk and implementing cost-effective deterrents. The CAPPS system was initially used for screening individuals who might attempt to bomb a passenger jet. It has since been expanded to screen for possible hijackers as well.
